Today, NEWS & NOTES begins Crossing the Divide with a look at two mentoring programs that helped blacks move to the next level.
One is in Atlanta for high-school students.
We'll hear more about that in a moment.
But first, a program that strives to get young black executives to stick with major firms and reach top management.
It's run by Robert Toigo Foundation, based in Oakland, California.
The group recently reported that one of the biggest challenges today is keeping black executives on Wall Street.
When NPR's Farai Chideya spoke with Nancy Sims, president of the Toigo Foundation, she asked Sims what pushed people of color out of these firms.

Primarily it's one of feeling of disconnect with the organization and that comes often by way of lack of access to, I think, improminent(ph) deal flow - things that really measure performance and talent and potential - not being heard and not having a voice that moves up within the organization to understand clearly what it takes in terms of performance, and connections to move ahead.
And feeling of being passed over for opportunities, particularly for promotion.
And there's certainly a lack of alignment with compensation, and in clarity around what it takes to get the types of increases and the promotional opportunities that an individual is deserving of.
Now, your foundation deals directly with people who are moving into Wall Street jobs and financial service jobs.
How does what you do keep them from falling off of the edge and getting marginalized?

The Toiga Foundation made a commitment about five years ago that our job was not simply to identify students who were attending business school and pursing careers in finance, but really to be a partner with them once they were in the finance industry.
So we provide on going career counseling and support.
We serve as advocates where appropriate, and we also provide an ongoing leadership development curriculum.
How do companies respond?
Do they look at your research and say, oh no, that doesn't happen here.
Or when you advocate for someone who is a young professional, do they say, I think you're out of line?
What we have seen to date is that the firms and the industry over all has embraced the survey.
They have applauded us for initiating it and have encouraged us to do more.

We have taken the added step of actually bringing forward members of our alumni to an organization to talk to them first hand about their experiences and to help them understand what systems and practices they have within their company and how they might be modified.

Are there ever things that happened that aren't just a matter of who gets mentoring in the workplace, but also just how people are perceived in terms of their relative power and what you can ask of them?
I think ultimately what were supporting is a group of individuals who are bringing anywhere from three to five years pre-MBA experience.
They're graduating from the top institutions in the country, and they're very focused on their careers once they're in finance.

The issue really at hand for Toigo participants, has been that they've succeeded over that three to four years of entry-level opportunity, and now they want to know what's the next step to move forward.
And that's what we understand to be less clear for the individual when they're in the role.
How specifically does this affect African-Americans?
What sorts of numbers are there in African-American participation in these key jobs?
For the Toigo population that is the predominate group, and certainly, for the survey, that was our largest respondent pool of roughly 60 percent.
I would say that one of the areas where we encourage all of the Toigo participants, but specifically for African-Americans, to really build their networks.
I think that that is the most critical area of growth and support that many has failed to exercise to the fullest.
The absence of having that on a consistent basis has led to, I think, the numbers for African-Americans to be much lower than desired.
